questions.text: The Secular trend is best demonstrated by
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In a line diagram, the frequency of an event (number of diseased people) is represented along the Y axis, and time along the X axis

Best way to demonstrate Secular trend is Line diagram, because it shows changes over time clearly.

Secular trend:

  • Long-term changes in the occurrence of a disease, showing a consistent upward or downward pattern over several years or decades.
  • May have short-term fluctuations, but the overall direction remains steady (either increase or decrease).

Examples:

  • Increasing trends(historically): Coronary heart disease, lung cancer, diabetes in developed countries (past ~50 years).
  • Later decline: These same diseases have shown a downward trend in some regions after public health measures.

Explanation of Other Options:

Bar graph(Option B): Better for comparing discrete categories at one point in time, not continuous trends.

Stem-leaf plot(Option C): Displays distribution of a small dataset, not suitable for long-term trends.

Box and whisker plots(Option D): Summarises distribution, median, and variability; doesn't show trends over time.

choices.text: Occurs in more than 1 incubation period
The epidemic curve falls very slowly

questions.text: True about the point source epidemic is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Features of a point source epidemic curve

  • Has a single peak
  • No secondary waves
  • All cases fall within one Incubation period
  • Epidemic curve rises and falls sharply
  • An epidemic tends to be explosive
  • Examples:
    • Food poisoningfrom a single contaminated meal, chemical exposure from a one-time leak.
    • The Chernobyl tragedyis a one-time exposure from a common source

Incubation Period:

Defined as the time interval between invasion by an infectious agent and the appearance of the first sign or symptom of the disease.

Factors Affecting the Incubation Period:

  • Generation timeof the pathogen.
  • Infective dose(larger dose often shortens the period).
  • Portal of entry(different entry points can affect timing).
  • Individual susceptibility(immunity, age, nutrition, etc.).

Importance in Epidemiology:

  • Tracing source of infection & contacts:
    • Short incubation → easier to trace (e.g., food poisoning).
    • Long incubation → more complex due to many possible exposures.
  • Determining period of surveillance/quarantine: Usually equal to the maximum incubation period.
  • Prophylaxis & Immunization: Knowledge helps in preventing illness (e.g., giving immunoglobulins after exposure).
  • Identifying susceptible contacts: Helps decide who should receive preventive measures.
  • Prognosis estimation: In some diseases (e.g., rabies, tetanus), shorter incubation → worse prognosis.

Explanation of Other Options:

Occurs in more than 1 incubation period(Option A): If cases keep appearing over multiple incubation periods, that pattern suggests person-to-person (propagated) spread or intermittent/continuous exposure, not a single exposure event.

The exposure is continuous(Option C): Continuous common-source epidemics have ongoing exposure (e.g., contaminated water supply) and produce a plateau or prolonged hump on the curve. Point-source exposure is brief or single-time, not continuous.

The epidemic curve falls very slowly(Option D): A slow, prolonged fall is characteristic of continuous or propagated epidemics (or a mix). A point-source curve typically falls quickly after the peak because there are no new exposures to replenish cases.

choices.text: Cases include both people who have been exposed and those who have not been exposed

questions.text: Which of the following is characteristic of a single-exposure, common-vehicle outbreak
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Single-exposure, common-vehicle outbreak is the characteristic ofpoint source epidemic. Explosive, fits to point source epidemic
  • Explosive refers to a sudden, sharp rise in caseswithin a short period (usually within one incubation period) after exposure.

Features of a point source epidemic curve

  • Has a single peak
  • No secondary waves
  • All cases fall within one Incubation period
  • An epidemic tends to be explosive

Explanation of Other Options:

Frequent secondary cases(Option A): Secondary cases happen when the disease spreads person-to-person after the initial exposure (e.g., measles, influenza).A single-exposure common-vehicle outbreak (e.g., contaminated food served once) does not usually have secondary transmission because the source is not ongoing.

Increasing severity with increasing age(Option B): Severity varying with age is disease-specific (e.g., hepatitis A more severe in adults), but it is not a defining feature of single-exposure, common-vehicle outbreaks.

Cases include both people who have been exposed and those who have not been exposed(Option D): In a common-vehicle outbreak, cases occur only among exposed individuals (e.g., those who ate the contaminated food).

questions.text: All are true regarding a propagated epidemic except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

No secondary wave is a feature of point source epidemic where as secondary wave is characteristic of Propagated epidemics.

Propagated epidemics:

  • Spread from person to person(Option C ruled out)
  • The height of secondary waves increases
  • It stops once herd immunity is attained(Option D ruled out)
  • The disease spreads over successive incubation periods, So progresses slowly.(Option A ruled out).

questions.text: Silent epidemic of the century
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Stroke, cognitive decline, and vascular dementia are known as the silent epidemic of the 21st century.

choices.text: Duration more than one incubation period
Rapid rise and fall of the epidemic curve

questions.text: True about continuous common source epidemics
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Continuous common source epidemic occurs when exposure to the source of infection is prolonged over time.

  • Exposure: Continuous (days, weeks, or longer)(Option D ruled out).
  • Duration: More than one incubation periodof the disease
  • Epidemic curve: Rise is gradual, plateau can be maintained, decline gradual(Option C ruled out)
  • Secondary attack rate: Usually low (because cases are due to ongoing exposure, not person-to-person spread)(Option A ruled out)
  • Continuous common source epidemicsmay also rise to a peak and then fall cases falling in a span of more than one incubation period. This implies that there is an ongoing source of contamination. E.g., a public well contaminated with cholera bacilli

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of a cyclic trend in epidemiology?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Waning of herd immunity is a cause for the cyclical trend

Cyclic Trend in Epidemiology:

  • Cyclic trends refer to the occurrence of certain diseases in repeated cycles over short or long periods, ranging from days to years.
  • Main cause:Variations in herd immunity within the population.
  • After an epidemic, immunity levels in the community are high, resulting in a decrease in disease incidence. Over time, new susceptible individuals are born or immunity wanes, causing another rise in cases.
  • Understanding disease cyclicity helps in forecasting outbreaks and implementing timely preventive measures.

Examples:

  • Measles(pre-vaccination era): Peaks every 2-3 years due to natural variations in herd immunity.
  • Rubella: Peaks every 6-9 years.
  • Influenza pandemicsoccur every 7-10 years due to antigenic variation of the virus.
  • Non-disease example: Automobile accidentsin the US: More frequent on weekends, especially Saturdays (weekly cyclic pattern).

Mechanism:

  • After an epidemic, many individuals in the community are immune.
  • Over time, susceptible individuals accumulate (due to new births or waning immunity).
  • Once the proportion of susceptibles crosses a threshold, another epidemic can occur.

Explanation of Other Options:

Environmental changes(Option B): These typically produce seasonal patterns (annual or seasonal peaks), not multi-year cycles. Example: rainy season → more malaria; winter → more influenza (seasonal).

Nutritional factors(Option C): Nutritional changes usually cause secular (long-term) trends, slow increases or decreases over years/decades (e.g., decline in rickets with improved diet).

Short-term fluctuations(Option D): Short-term fluctuations describe outbreaks/epidemics or weekly patterns (e.g., more road accidents on weekends). These are transient and irregular, not the repeated multi-year oscillations characteristic of cyclic trends.

choices.text: Measles is more dangerous than mumps
Mumps is more dangerous than measles
Measles is more infectious than mumps
Measles is more common than mumps

questions.text: The secondary attack rate of measles is more than mumps. What is the conclusion?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

As the secondary attack rate of measles is more than mumps, so, Measles is more infectious than mumps

Secondary attack rate:

The Secondary Attack Rate is the proportion of susceptible contacts who develop a particular disease within the incubation period following exposure to a primary case.

  • The primary case is always excluded from both the numerator and the denominator
  • The denominator ideally includes only susceptibles(if identification is possible).
  • Mainly used for acute, short communicable period diseases(e.g., measles, chickenpox).
  • Less applicable for diseases with long infectious periods(e.g., tuberculosis).

Applications

  • Measuring Infectivity: A higher SAR means higher person-to-person transmissibility.
  • Epidemic Studies: Used in point source and propagated epidemics.
  • Vaccine Effectiveness: Comparing SAR in vaccinated vs. unvaccinated groups.
  • Identifying Communicability: It can help determine if a disease of unknown cause is infectious.

Step 1: Find out Food food-specific attack rate

choices.text: Time gap between primary & secondary case
Time gap between the index and the Primary case
Time taken for a person from the receipt of infection to develop maximum infectivity
Time taken from infection till a person infects another person

questions.text: In epidemiology, the serial interval refers to which of the following periods?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The serial interval is the time gap between the onset of symptoms in a primary case and the onset of symptoms in a secondary case infected by that primary case.
  • By recording the time interval between the primary and secondary cases for multiple such chains, we can construct a distribution of serial intervals.
  • This distribution helps estimate the incubation periodof the disease.

Example:

  • In a small, closed group such as a family, an infectious disease outbreak often begins with a primary case.
  • After a short interval, secondary cases appear, usually 2-3 in number, within the same group.

Explanation of Other Options:

Time gap between the index and the Primary case(Option B): The Index case is the first case identified in an investigation, which may or may not be the true primary case (the actual first infected person in that setting). This measures an administrative gap, not a transmission interval.

Time taken for a person from the receipt of infection to develop maximum infectivity(Option C): This is closer to the generation time or peak infectivity period, not the serial interval. Peak infectivity may occur before, during, or after symptom onset, depending on the disease.

Time taken from infection till a person infects another person(Option D): This is the generation time (infection-to-infection) and is usually slightly shorter than the serial interval if pre-symptomatic transmission occurs.

choices.text: Till the last secondary case occurs
No new case reported for the incubation period of the disease since the last case
No new case reported for twice the incubation period of the disease since the last case
No new case reported for six months since the last case

questions.text: The area is declared free of epidemic
questions.solution:
Explanation:

An area is declared free of epidemic till no new cases are reported for twice the Incubation period of the disease from the last case

choices.text: Verification of diagnosis → confirmation of the existence of an epidemic → defining the population at risk → rapid search for all cases and their characteristic
Defining population at risk → rapid search for all cases and their characteristic → verification of diagnosis → confirmation of the existence of an epidemic
Defining population at risk → rapid search for all cases and their characteristic → confirmation of the existence of an epidemic → verification of diagnosis

questions.text: Select the appropriate order for carrying out an epidemic investigation
questions.solution:
Explanation:

STEPS IN OUTBREAK INVESTIGATION

  1. Verification of diagnosis
  2. Confirmation of the existence of an epidemic
  3. Defining the population at risk
  4. Rapid search for all cases and their characteristics
  5. Data analysis
  6. Formulation of a hypothesis
  7. Testing hypothesis
  8. Evaluation of ecological factors
  9. Further investigation of the population at risk
  10. Writing the report

questions.text: How many factors are there in the BEINGS model of disease causation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

BEINGS MODEL consists of the following 9 components

B→ Biological factors

B→ Behavioural

E→ Environmental factors

I→ Immunological factors

N→ Nutritional factors

G→ Genetic factors

S→ Social factors

S→ Services factors

S→ Spiritual factors

choices.text: A necessary but not sufficient cause
A sufficient but not necessary cause

questions.text: Factor A, B,or C can each individually cause a certain disease without the other two factors, but only when followed by exposure to factor X. Exposure to factor X alone is not followed by the disease, but the disease never occurs in the absence of exposure to factor X. Factor X is known as
questions.solution:
Explanation:

According to the Causal Pie model, also known as the Component cause model→

There are 4 types of causal relationships

  1. Necessary and Sufficient
  2. Necessary but Not Sufficient
  3. Sufficient but Not Necessary
  4. Neither Necessary Nor Sufficient

Necessary factor means → Disease will occur only if this factor is present

Sufficient factor means → this factor alone cannot cause the disease

questions.text: Spot maps are used for a disease in epidemiology for the depiction of
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Spot maps use dots or other symbols to show where each case lived or was exposed.
  • It is useful for showing the geographic distribution of cases to trace the causes of infection or exposure

questions.text: Dengue in the community usually has 45-50 cases weekly. Last week, the case burden was 48. What type of disease is it in this community
questions.solution:
Explanation:

EPIDEMIC→

  • No: of cases >Mean + 2 SD
  • The occurrence of a new case
  • Eliminated or eradicated disease
  • EPIDEMIC
  • ENDEMIC→It refers to the constant presence of a disease or infectious agent within a given geographic area. The term "hyperendemic" expresses that the disease is constantly present at a high incidence and/or prevalence rate and affects all age groups equally; and the term "holoendemic" a high level of infection beginning early in life and affecting most of the child population.
  • SPORADIC The cases occur irregularly, haphazardly from time to time, and generally infrequently. The cases are so few and separated widely in space and time, e.g., tetanus, herpes-zoster, and meningococcal meningitis.
  • PANDEMIC An epidemic occurring over a very wide area, crossing international boundaries, and usually affecting a large number of people. Examples are influenza pandemics and cholera pandemics.

questions.text: A Disease is imported into a country that would not have occurred otherwise
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • EXOTIC Diseases that are imported into a country in which they do not otherwise occur.
  • ZOONOSES: An infection or infectious disease transmissible under natural conditions from vertebrate animals to man. May be enzootic or epizootic - e.g., rabies, plague, bovine tuberculosis, anthrax, brucellosis, salmonellosis, endemic typhus, hydatidosis, kyasanur forest disease, monkeypox, lassa fever, etc
  • EPIZOOTIC: An outbreak (epidemic) of disease in an animal population. E.g.: the agents of anthrax, brucellosis, rabies, influenza, and Japanese encephalitis.
  • EPIDEMIC An outbreak (epidemic) of disease in a bird population
  • ENZOOTIC An endemic occurring in animals, e.g., anthrax, rabies, brucellosis, bovine tuberculosis, endemic typhus, and tick typhus
